Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This class should literally be mandatory for everyone who wants to graduate from Yale.  If Columbia can mandate that all students essentially take Directed Studies, Yale can mandate that all of its graduates have a basic understanding of ethnic studies.  This being said, the course spans far broader than simply ethnic studies.  Not only did ER&M 200 remind me of how much I love history, but it integrates studies of ethnicity, race, gender, capitalism, and critical histories from all corners of human society into a course that both is an expos of a fantastic major and far more comprehensive than even its very widely-encompassing name--"Introduction to Ethnicity, Race, and Migration"--suggests.  The course teaches lessons that many more technical courses at Yale tend to overlook--it eloquently and powerfully clarifies that all things have a history, and that these histories do not simply constitute the past, but in fact encompass our present.  Please take this class.

I was able to explore race-relations and colonialism in a global context, which was extremely valuable. This is also showed me the interconnectedness of the experiences of people of color throughout the world.
I gained a deeper and more sophisticated understanding of many topics I was already familiar with, such as the slave market and the extermination of Native peoples.
Overview of ethnic studies, race theory, Third World movements, civil rights, migration, etc
This was a great introductory course to the ER&M department. It covered a lot of material and broad topics focusing on American society but talked about global issues as well.
As a senior ER&M major, I was familiar with a lot of the material we covered, but the course was an insightful and helpful overview of many topics I hadn't engaged with in a long time.
The various overt and covert ways minority groups in different countries have been discriminated, oppressed, and even killed due to the majority's xenophobia.

I learned a lot about the mechanics of race, ethnicity, and migration. I also developed more information to challenge the heteronormative eurocentric history that we are often taught. This course also helped me learn more about using archival texts in research and using alternative mediums like music to explore societal issues.
Contextualizing imperialism and colonialism and a greater understanding and empathy for immigration and issues caused by colonialism
I learned a lot about the history of racism across the globe.
Reading, research, visiting and accessing archives.
readings, writing, synthesis

Learned how to analyze texts and tie them with concepts we were learning throughout the course. I also definitely learned more about how ethnicity, race, and migration issues today relate to and stem from deeply rooted historical problems.

I am so happy I took this course! Intro courses can sometimes be dull, especially because I had already taken a lot of ER&M classes, but this was not! The lectures and readings push you to think about all the topics in a really essential way, and by the end of the course, the learning was organized into four themes that perfectly encapsulated what we had learned.
I learned how to evaluate cultural and archival texts throughout assignments in class.
I gained so much knowledge that I did not have before, it was as thought I was re-learning everything I had ever learned before or thought I knew about before.

this course is a great overview of the field of ethnic studies and provides many entrypoints for majors and non-majors alike. I learned valuable skills and read important texts in the field of de-colonial and anti-racist work.
I honestly learned basically nothing.
A way to reconceptualize how we think about history, from the perspective of those who have been oppressed, rather than those doing the oppressing

Intro to ERM was a wonderful class and Alicia is an amazing lecturer. I love the discussion topics brought up by the class, challenging the tradition narrative of history, which is usually told from the side of the oppressor.
Introduction to historic social, political, and economic processes and their effect on constructions of race, national identity.

I gained very important knowledge in regards to the development of racial and ethnic concepts that arise from societal development enforced by migration and oppressive powers. This has enabled me to view historical events in a much more critical light.
Critical thinking, deeper world and historical understanding

Looked and learned about history through the perspectives of those groups that have been oppressed - often material that is not presented to the reader of a standard history textbook about this country.  Learned to always question rules that are made to limit us in some type of way because they could be rooted in ideologies that are not consistent with the promotion of equality.

I feel like I gained a great, broad background in the study of ethnicity, race, and migration. I learned how to interpret both historical and contemporary literary, artistic, and primary sources, and I feel like I gained many valuable insights into current topics and discussions in the field.

This course is the history you didnt get in high school. Aka, the history that matters the most. Please take this course! It gave me a comprehensive foundation of knowledge regarding how race came to be a social category and the different ways it is perpetuated and weaponized.

The course was a broad overview of the discipline of Ethnicity, Race and Migration. I gained an understanding of the ER&M approach to analyzing primary sources as well as of the primary preoccupations of the field--genocide, human rights, colonialism, etc. As a woman and person of color, this course, with highly diverse enrollment, was wonderful because its material touched on my people's story. I learned so much about myself in the process.
I learned so much about marginalized groups through history, and how marginalization continues today.

Wow, I learned so much in this class. Coming from a very conservative educational background, I felt like I relearned so many topics in American and world history from a completely different angle. This class just gave me a totally different way of interacting with and thinking about history. I also learned a lot of new skills for how to interpret and use a variety of sources in academic work, from writings to art to music.

More confidence in writing research papers 
Archival paper initially pretty daunting just because of number of sources coupled with the short page limit, but ended up being great in terms of bettering synthesizing skills.

Taking this a junior, with a fair number of ER&M courses under my belt, this course served as powerful site of synthesis, drawing connections between fields and methodologies that I'd previously only encountered in isolation.

This class helped me hone skills of text dissection and contextualization, concise summary of information and arguments, and investigation of linking aspects of various sources. I learnt a lot of basic historical knowledge about the US and the world, along with a method of questioning and challenging accepted norms that could otherwise go unchallenged.

I learned how to engage with a lot of different media with critical and imaginative frameworks. I learned and unlearned, in that I acquired a broader and deeper understanding of the histories that produce our current context, and many different ways of coming to know and imagine those histories. I learned to do scholarly work with a keen awareness of my own history in relation to the work. I gained insight into the way in which legacies of colonialism, imperialism, and resistance have shaped everything from the built environment to the way I've learned to formulate thought and approach problems.
New perspectives on the concepts of ethnicity, race, and migration. History of construction and control of different races.

This class provides an extremely useful framework for viewing and reevaluating modern history, particularly American. Professor Camacho is extraordinary and she brings in fascinating guest lectures. The TFs in Spring 2018 were also really excellent. If you don't think a lot about ethnicity and race, or even if you do, this class can change/challenge/augment your views in meaningful ways.

The course is a broad exposition of the entire Ethnicity, Race, and Migration program and makes an effort to cover as much subject area as possible.  This is both an asset and a complication of the course--the breadth of material covered is both mesmerizing and tantalizing.  Even after learning so much as part of the class, I am left wanting to learn so much more.  However, this incompleteness is intentionally embedded in the course as the titular "Introduction" offered by the course is meant to both inform and entice--an important function for an important program.  Professor Schmidt-Camacho also makes her devotion to social justice known through her work and her role as a professor.  Knowing the frequent inaccessibility of academia to its own students and those who seek its information (Yale is a fantastic place to see this problem in action), she strives to make the course both academically and materially accessible--as part of this, the readings are (1) profound, diverse, and engaging and (2) available as electronic texts on Orbis or as free PDFs in Canvas.  Please take this class.
Sections are poorly structured, lectures move too slowly.

Strengths: The material was interesting, and the guest lecturers were extremely engaging and insightful.

Weakness: Lectures can be hard to follow and the power points don'e have enough information to take notes.

strengths- low workload, students and teaching staff that deeply care about the material

weaknesses- it was so easy to get lost in macro-scale concepts and become overwhelmed by the material

A strength of the course was that students were treated as equal intellectual partners with something to contribute to everyone else's understanding. Prof. Camacho often asked us during lecture for our perspectives on the primary texts or on the questions she brought up during lecture. A weakness was that lectures often operated on a level of sophistication that we found difficult to get excited about or be engaged with. The questions we considered were so broad and far-reaching that we sometimes didn't have much of an entry point.
Good intro/overview course!

I think one way to improve the course is to organize the lecture by themes or similar topics. I found that there was no set order to the lectures so in that sense the course was a little hard to follow.
Incredible course! I wish I had taken it as a first year. I don't have any suggestions for improvement.

A picture speaks for a thousand words. Because this course covers so much in so little time, perhaps one way to help students remember the content is to share a real life story of someone for each of the areas studied. In some cases this was done, in others not.

I really liked that we had guest lectures from other professors in the department, because it helped me gauge whether I was interested in exploring ER&M in the future. I also really appreciated the breadth and depth of issues we covered, from the Bosnian Genocide to Slave Markets in Louisiana to postcolonial Jamaica. Professor Camacho was also such a wonderful, supportive instructor.
Lectures were extremely long and then you also had section, pick one
This course was incredible. It was very much a survey of ethnicity, race, and migration. I learned so much. Perhaps if the readings were shorter it would be easier to keep up.
Really good intro/overview of ER&M as a field and as a department at Yale
The only suggestion I would add is that it would be cool to take a page from Professor Chauncey's book and play music from last years global playlist before each lecture.
Strength is that it provides a comprehensive view of history that students were typically never exposed to and it is curated incredibly gracefully by Camacho.
Great survey course of what the major has to offer.

Strengths: Very interesting concepts, interesting discussion sections, global playlist at the end of the semester is really fun
Weaknesses: LOTS of readings (at least for me), lecture consisted of professor Camacho sharing her insights and explaining concepts that made it somewhat difficult for me to comprehend what exactly we need to know for exams/papers

Strengths: Professor Camacho, the TFs, the lectures, the format of the course was very accessible
Weaknesses: The readings were so wonderful, but many were too long to read comprehensively so I wish they had been a little shorter. Also, the global playlist event was too long - I think it would have been cooler to present in section and then the TFs could compile a song list and share it with the whole class so we could continue listening to the songs.

The material is super engaging and section is great resource for us to flush out our thoughts. I wish we could spend more time on certain sections and themes, but I get that there is a lot to cover in a set timespan!

This course I think covered many important issues and was a great introduction to the ethnicity race and migration major like it said it was going to be. I also think it was great how it was able to tie its topics of conversation to current examples. A weakness could have possibly been the order in which the topics went in, sometimes it wasnt very clear to me why it went that way. The guest lectures were also amazing. Additionally, I feel like this course made me more comfortable as a student because you werent focused on getting the grade you wanted since they werent harsh, it was easier to actually immerse myself in the course and internalize what I was learning because of that.
This course is really basic information. Its an ok course but should not be required for the major. If it continues to be required for the major, it should go more in depth and not be such a gut.

I think the strengths of this class lie heavily in the course readings which I found to be extremely interesting and thought provoking. I enjoyed lecture as well, but I often found it a bit hard to follow along, as the slides were hard to take notes from.
Strength: breadth of national and international themes covered
The lectures by Professor Camaccho were amazing and having guest lecturers who specialized in the topics we were reading about that week was also a great plus to the class.
The lectures were my favorite part of the course. Professor Schmidt Camacho was engaging and interesting and made me excited to go to class.
Incredible course- everyone should take
Felt like the class was very well organized and section was awesome.  Work was clearly described on Canvas and easily accessible.

Strengths - super interesting lectures, amazing professor, interesting course material

Weaknesses - sometimes, greater summary of the readings in section could be helpful

The strengths were the different mediums analyzed--court documents, music, poetry, to name a few. Professor Camacho's enthusiasm and respect for the material were a big factor in my engagement with the course. The Teaching Assistants were also clearly devoted to the curriculum (at least mine was). I also very much appreciated the guest lectures. They gave me an opportunity to learn about related faculty members and other approaches to the field of ER&M. Overall, the course seemed to have a lot of care given to its design. 

The course's broadness is both a strength and weakness. Sometimes, when Professor Camacho/the guest lecturer presented us with a historical overview of a topic, it was hard to distinguish was merely important for background info, and which information tied into broader course themes like personhood, resistance, etc.

strengths: knowledge of all professors and TA's; expansiveness of course material to offer many stories and perspectives 
weaknesses: lack of engagement between Professor Camacho and students

This is frankly just an awesome course, especially for an intro class. I think it might be my favorite course I've taken at Yale, and definitely one of the ones of I've learned the most in. Professor Camacho is truly the nicest and most caring professor I've ever had, and she's a great scholar too. The material is fascinating, although there's so much to cover, that you won't always have time to go as deep as you'd like. The assignments and exams are also interesting and thought-provoking. I appreciated how they were very fair, designed for you to share your knowledge and discuss what interests you most, rather than to stress you out. Overall, I just can't say enough things. Perhaps my only criticism is that the guest lectures sometimes didn't feel that connected to other things we were talking about, but at the same time I really enjoyed hearing from other scholars in the field.
This class is very open and welcoming to al majors! Occasionally a little slow but overall a really informative and interesting class

Weaknesses:
Really appreciate you Camacho but sometimes hard to grasp onto exactly what you were saying when you lectured. I wish the lectures could've been a bit more accessible. These are ideas that, arguably, everyone should at the very least know about, but information on them is delivered in a way that's . .. arcane. 
Section could also be a little awkward, too, but I think that's almost inevitable. 
Strengths: 
A really forgiving course. Please hold onto this aspect.

Prof. Camacho is an extraordinary lecturer - a truly superb teacher. Listening to her speak for 2 and a half hours a week was simply a joy. It was sometimes difficult to fully delve into the nuances and intricacies of the material in the fifty minute sections, but still felt that we all gained so much from the readings' interactions with the content of Prof. Camacho's lectures. The guest lecturers also provided fascinating counterpoints to Prof. Camacho's style, broadening the scope of the course so richly.

I think the scope of this class is a great strength as it allows the diverse group of students sitting in lecture to connect to various different parts of the syllabus. I wish that more time had been spent in section as though some of the conversations had there were really great, we met for so little that it was difficult to truly establish the level of trust and comfort needed to form a grounded community that engaged such topics willingly and without self consciousness. I also sometimes thought the lectures could have benefitted by being only an hour instead of an hour and fifteen minutes. The readings were amazing though. I was almost always excited and captivated by everything I had to read for this class. It always left me thinking beyond the classroom.

The reading list was absolutely spectacular. Professor Schmidt Camacho was one of the best professors I've ever had the opportunity to learn from. Her lectures were each publishable in their own right. The only weakness of this course is that I wish I had three more years to engage more deeply with related materials and my peers about the subjects we discussed.

Strengths: great lectures, engaging sections, interesting peers, meaningful assignments. Weaknesses: none, in particular. Sometimes you feel a little helpless, but I think that's the nature of the subject (i.e. many of the problems described in the class feel intractable).

Please.  Take.  This.  Class.  Not only is the course's subject matter profoundly important in understanding the world(s) that we have inherited from history, but also in understanding the ways that power structures perpetuate themselves independently of how people might deplore them.  The class integrates a wonderful depth in engaging with cultural and ethnic studies and also forwards a materialist (i.e. class-based) analysis of history.  To add to the incredible depth and breadth of the course, the second half of the semester includes several guest speakers including in my semester Daniel HoSang, Inderpal Grewal, David Simon, Ana Ramos-Zayas, and equally fantastic scholars of ethnic studies and adjacent fields.  This list is likely to expand as new professors come to Yale and other professors' availability changes!
Yes! It gives a great overview of the white supremacy and marginalized backgrounds and how it shaped America

If you have significant background in ethnic studies, unless it's a requirement for the major, I wouldn't recommend it. If this is a new topic area for you, I would say it's a low-workload class that will give you a broad background on many areas of ethnic studies. Lectures, although they move slowly, can have some great and interesting insights.
Yes, it provides pertinent foundational information about Ethnicity, Race , and Migration.
yes! everyone should engage with er&m as a way of viewing the world. it can change your life!

Yes, with reservations. If you are committed to big, theoretical questions about the nature of racism, decolonization, and liberation, then this is the class for you. Otherwise, if you're already familiar with the topics, then you might want to shop an ER&M seminar.

If you're not an ER&M major and are looking to take an ER&M class I would opt for Intro Third World Studies. If you are a major this class is required. The material of ER&M 200 is interesting and Camacho is a great professor but the lectures could be a bit boring.
Yes underclqssmen
I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in issues of race and social justice.
Take ER&M 200!!!!! I took this as a senior ER&M major, and one of my biggest regrets at Yale is not taking it sooner. ER&M will change your life!!!
Yes, a version of it should be available and required to all students.

I would totally recommend this course to another student. If you are interested in issues of race and identity, it provides so much engaging material. If you haven't been exposed to these types of issues, it will change the way you consider society, American history, and the world itself.
Depends on the student

I really would recommend this course! It is very well organized and you really really learn a lot. The lecture is so wonderful and so easy to understand. It really gives you a sense of how deeply steeped in racism we are, which is kind of upsetting, but nonetheless important to grasp.
Yes

Whatever your major is, this course provides a necessary background in the history and theory surrounding ER&M. It is a must take for any Yale student who cares at all about the state of the world, and who is interested in having a solid groundwork for thinking about race, internationalism and other related topics.

YES. Please do, especially if these sorts of classes are not the types of things you are typically into. This class is essential to beginning a decolonizing mental process. I was forced to think of things in ways that I had never before. The questions may sometimes be difficult but they are necessary. The class overall is also chill. The TA's are cool and Alicia is an angel.
I would recommend this class to every Yale student just because it touches on many important histories that relate to today.

I highly recommend IF you are really interested in learning about the topic. I'm not an ER&M major and I had never learned anything related to it before but I was fascinated by the course and the concepts we discussed. I also recommend it if you like to analyze texts or simply read some interesting pieces; it's a great way to satisfy your humanities' requirement. Also Professor Camacho is amazing!

I would recommend for any student to take this class if they can fit it in their schedule. It was very informative and included both historical and current issues that aren't often covered in high school classes, but are more relevant, in my opinion.

YES - I think this should be a required course for all Yale students. It gives an overview to histories, concepts and issues that are pressing and fundamental in every field of study/job that exists today. Please please please take this class!!!
Yes! This is an excellent introductory course, regardless of your major. Professor Camacho really facilitates your learning and is willing to accommodate the needs of  her students.

I would recommend this course, even to those that arent typically interested in these courses because it does give you a lot of information that is important to just know as a human being and it opens your eyes to a lot of things that before you might have superficially understood or never even thought about.
yes! if you are at all interested in ethnic studies or want a great new framework with which to view the world, take this class!
Not really, unless you are looking for a super easy gut. The lectures are fairly boring and cover super basic information.
Yes, it is a good introduction to the field, Prof. Camacho is brilliant and the readings are interesting and cover many subjects

Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone of any major, especially history/social science majors because I think it is important to learn about the systems that function to create the socioeconomic and political inequalities that drive so many issues in society in today.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes! Especially for those who wouldnt otherwise be exposed to major trends and methodologies in ethnic studies.
Yes, I would because I think it is important for everyone to understand race dynamics in contemporary time in conjunction to historical analysis.
Absolutely
Professor Camacho makes this class amazing
Yes, I was engaged and very interested in the material presented in class.

Yes! Any student interested in ER&M should take the class. The course material is varied and interesting, lectures are interesting, and there arent too many readings. Professor Camacho is amazing and so kind.
Yes.
Yes! To echo the other evaluations, this is a must-take before you leave Yale.

I would recommend this course in a heartbeat. I don't think that every class is for everyone, however. I recommend it to students interested in analyzing histories and narratives that have already been taught in schools from a different point of view. I recommend it as well to students interested in learning about universal themes--maintaining a sense of one's humanity in the face of grave violence and oppression, for example. I think this course is a must-take for all Yale students.

Yes! Professor Camacho cares about her students so much, and the TA's really want to facilitate student discussion about the course material. It gives you an incredibly new perspective about how to look at people of color, including the language we use when talking about marginalized groups and the way power persists throughout history.

I can't recommend this class enough. If you can take it, absolutely do it, no matter what your major or your interests are. Don't be put off by the first few classes if you feel a little bored or overwhelmed. It takes a little time to adjust, but once you open your mind to this class, you will be amazed by the things you learn. I especially recommend this class for people who are not very well acquainted with or interested in the field of ER&M, because you will get the most out of it. You'll discover new ways of thinking and learning, and the ideas you learn will change the ways you think about many other things in your life. Seriously, if you're considering it, just do it.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! So important for all students to have a basic understanding of ethnicity, race and migration.
I would recommend this course to someone that doesn't really think too much race, ethnicity, and/or migration.

Regardless of whether or not you plan on majoring in ER&M, you should definitely take the course to learn more about processes and structures of racialization in a multi-racial, international context. Professor Camacho is incredible and this is a great gateway course for those who are interested in ER&M but also in learning more about the production of race in the United States and post-colonial territories.

Absolutely. One of the best ways to encounter Prof. Camacho's extraordinary scholarship and a thorough and potent introduction to the major strands of history, methodology, and social movements within ER&M. Touches upon everything from left economic theory to decolonizing language.

I honestly think this class should be some sort of required class or distributional requirement. It is such a necessary foundation for being a critical and educated individual especially in the tumultuous political, environmental, and social state we currently find in the US, and arguably the world. It was a lecture so allowed arguably a level of lesser engagement than a seminar, but also had section where you could express personal ideas, and Professor Camacho did often make lecture interactive. A great fifth class, and a great class in general. Assignments were fair, self-driven, and enjoyable to complete.

Absolutely. This is one of the two best courses I've taken in my time at Yale. There are few courses that will not only change the way you think about your own political subjectivity and relation to the world, but also change the way you think about what how you want to shape your life in light of those lessons.
Definitely, for many reasons but, first and foremost, Professor Camacho!
